reviewText: This DVD is strictly an interview/documentary film, with just bits and pieces of Hendrix performing. Sound boring? NO WAY. All of the interviewees shed fascinating light on Hendrix the man himself as well as his extraordinary body of work, and provide insightful, intelligent comments. Even some musicians whom I believe have been historically rather reticent from being interviewed, e.g. Chris Squire and Mick Taylor, step up to the mic and add some great stories. Chris's recounts of seeing the Experience in the early days are quite hilarious!I would consider the DVD "A Film About Jimi Hendrix" to be still the standard overall biopic on Hendrix, but this new DVD here is very complementary as a second reference and only has a little overlap of material, if any, with the "Film About" DVD. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED FOR HENDRIX FANS!!
summary: One of two indispensable films about Hendrix!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Boy Howdy!  This is an interesting DVD, going places that the 'official' biographies won't touch with a ten foot pole.  Definitely lacking in music, with either third party tunes or grinding noise, but making up for it by focusing on two things: Jimi's influence as a monster guitarist and the more controversial aspects of his life.  It's not all sex drugs and rock & roll, as Jimi's brother Leon gets extensive coverage (he is on the outs with the Family but gets his say here, worth the price to hear him alone) in both the main feature and in the bonus interviews.Eric Burdon, who made the claims of suicide at the death scene, gets to defend his view, which is also fascinating.  Additionally, Kathy Etchingham gets a fair amount of time to tell her story, and as Jimi's primary girlfriend she has a lot to say, all of which sounds like the truth to me.  Dave Mason is also heard from, talking studio technique, mostly, and Zoot Money is the elder statesman of British musicians.  Slash holds down the fort, doing a fine job both giving opinion and narrating.It is the opinions that makes this DVD valuable.  Drug usage is discussed, as is manager Michael Jeffries, both topics strictly forbidden in the Janie Hendrix authorized accounts.  Fairness is also evidence, so it's not all nodding out.  And it's great to hear from Lemmy, who brings a refreshing frankness to his statements.  So if you looking for something on the life and legacy of Jimi Hendrix and isn't afraid to voice conflicting and occasionally unflattering facts and opinions, this is where you will find it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Here's a DVD with many mysteries. Jimi Hendrix was one of the most gifted guitarists, recording artists and stage performers of the rock era - yet the DVD contains absolutely NO footage of him actually performing any of his own material and the brief clips are not only incomplete but of cover versions. (It's like a book about Picasso but without any illustrations). Hendrix' career history, and how he amalgamated and transcended many of the traditions of the so-called 'chitlin circuit' by incorporating psychedelia and free jazz is an absolutely fascinating story; the film eschews anything resembling linear story-telling in favor of random contemporary interviews with folks who worked closely with Hendrix. Hendrix' three completed LPs are masters of creative, innovative writing and yet the DVD has no real information about his creative process. These interviews are interspersed with grainy stock footage of Swinging London and late 1960s California. There's some uncorrected misinformation interspersed throughout - despite what Mick Taylor claims, Jimi Hendrix was not a paratrooper in Viet Nam, and although Hendrix used fuzz boxes extremely well he was not the first to do so (they were around in the early 1960s). The extras are senseless - do we really need ten minutes of silent footage of the Monkees AFTER Hendrix was removed from their tour? And aside from a complete performance of "Hey Joe," why aren't there any other actual Hendrix performances available?Look, if the producers were unable to license the clips that's fine. Just print a disclaimer on the DVD box stating that this is a documentary film and does not contain any complete performances.Before you dismiss this as the sort of cheap cash-in that companies like GoodTimes video used to clutter up bargain bins with, it has to be noted that there are two excellent interview subjects who almost make this DVD worthwhile. The first is Jimi Hendrix' younger brother Leon, who's been more or less purged from the 'official' story. I don't know to what degree everything that Leon says is believable, but the interviews are lively and give a much-needed human face to the proceedings. The second is Lemmy, bassist for Motorhead and former Hendrix roadie. Lemmy's got a reputation for shooting from the hip, being blunt, and anti-nostalgic and its these qualities that also bring something special to the DVD. As an aside, the ever-controversial Alan Douglas (who supervised many of the post-mortem Hendrix releases that have now been deleted from circulation) gets to give his two cents as well.If you're already a fan (and I'm a huge Hendrix fan), you'll find some useful and interesting things about this disk. But if you aren't yet a fan, this is an awful and confusing introduction to the legacy of the man who changed rock guitar for the better in the late 1960s. It's a poorly thought-out and poorly organized documentary that fails to capture how exciting Jimi Hendrix was and what an important influence he was on future generations of guitar players. (In this regard, more younger musicians than Slash should have been interviewed because without younger musicians testifying, an impression is given that Jimi's importance is largely historical). The 1973 documentary wasn't perfect, but it was coherent and it contained complete performances. I strongly suggest you scoop that film up if you haven't seen it and leave this one as an optional purchase for much, much later.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a very nice overview of Jimi as a player. Not an instructional DVD, but it covers his career and influence as a player. His brother is the real gem of this. You hear a lot of great stories about Jimi's upbringing that explains his personality. The thing this documentary give you is a lot of great stories you don't hear elsewhere with a minimum of the usual hero worship myths.I have all of the Classic Artist series and everyone of them is great. Highly recommended.
summary: Very good focus on Jimi the player
Title: N/A

reviewText: This dvd is a true homage to the man born Johnny Allen Hendrix, whose father, upon returning home from WWII, legally changed his firstborn son's name to James Marshall Hendrix, who was called Buster by his family, and who was known to all the world as Jimi Hendrix. What makes this homage dvd so great are all the stories from all the really great people who actually knew Jimi during his short life.The dvd begins in 1966 with Jimi Hendrix in England, where he first drew the attention of the world on himself with his first hit single, HEY JOE. It was here in London that a mere 3 people- Jimi Hendrix (1942-1970) on his fender stratocaster, Noel Redding (1945-2003) on bass and Mitch Mitchell (1946-2008) on drums filled the world with a new sound that blew us all away back then.After the dvd tells us stories of the great music of The Jimi Hendrix Experience, it then turns back the clock to the beginning of Jimi's life in Seattle, Washington. This is where Jimi's poverty and broken family life began, with a father named James Allen (Al) Hendrix in the service in WWII and a 17 year old mother named Lucille Jeter Hendrix alone in the States who named the baby after her old boyfriend Johnny and husband Allen. She was alone when she gave birth to baby Johnny the day after Thanksgiving on November 27, 1942. When Jimi's father came home after the war in 1945, he immediately changed 3 year old Johnny's name to James Marshall Hendrix, after himself and his brother Marshall. Johnny was now Jimmy and in the confusion, little Jimmy changed his own name to Buster, after Buster Crabbe, whom he loved from The Flash Gordon Films he saw at the local theatre.The dvd then takes us through Jimi's life through fascinating and wonderful stories from the following: LEON HENDRIX-Jimi's brother, whose touching stories of their early years totally make this dvd!; SLASH-of Guns N Roses, does a fabulous job narrating with commentaries; ERIC CLAPTON; MICKEY DOLENZ of The Monkees; ERIC BURDON of The Animals; MICK TAYLOR of The Rolling Stones; ZOOT MONEY-keyboard player; KATHY ETCHINGHAM-Jimi's ex-girlfriend; CHARLES CROSS-author; BEN PALMER-Cream road manager; DAVE MASON-guitarist, did All Along The Watchtower with Jimi; ALAN WHITE-drummer from Yes; JON BREWER-film maker; CHRIS SQUIRE-bass player from Yes; JOEY COVINGTON-drummer from Jefferson Airplane; GINGER BAKER-drummer for Cream; LEMMY KILMINSTER-Motorhead; ALAN DOUGLAS-record producer; PAUL RODGERS-singer for Free and Bad Co.; STEPHEN STILLS; HENRY DILTZ-rock photographer; BEV BEVAM-drummer from ELO; and many more.The personal stories all these heavyweights in Rock tell of their time spent with Jimi are worth their weight in gold, but it's Jimi's brother Leon who sheds the most light on Jimi's life. Leon shares the most touching stories from their childhood and of Jimi's early career before he became known worldwide in England. This dvd would be tremendous with just the stories alone, but there are fabulous old film clips of the places Jimi played at, bought his clothes at, where he lived, that just add to the story of his life in beautiful full color. Going back in time on film to the Whiskey A Go Go, Ronnie Scotts, The World's End, Granny Takes A Trip, Bag Of Nails, Olympia, the Chelsea Market, Marquee Club, Portabello Road and so many other great sixties clubs, shops and places is a fantastic delightful journey in itself! Then there are the fabulous photographs that just add so much to Jimi's personal life! This dvd covers Jimi's life, like nothing I've ever seen or read and I believe it's because of the close personal stories from his family, girlfriend, friends and bandmates. It is simply beyond tremendous!When I first heard The Jimi Hendrix Experience on the radio in 1967, I didn't know that this was a Seattle guitarist, who was shunned here in the States- especially in the South where they wouldn't even serve him food, became a success in England with 2 English musicians, then came back to the States to blow us all away with his performance at The Monterey Pop Festival, the only thing I knew, was HOW DOES HE MAKE THAT SOUND? Back in the late sixties, we only knew that here was a young musician who played like no one else on the planet. Jimi filled ever inch of space with sounds that seemed to go on forever! I now know that this gifted genius musician played his strat upside down, backwards, restrung for left handed playing with his fuzz box and the biggest Marshall Amps that would fill every bit of space, which no one to this day could ever come close to duplicate!The almost 2 hours of this dvd are completely filled with everything you would like to know about Jimi Hendrix, and added to that are the following Special Features: Henry Diltz's 8mm silent film The Monkees; Black and White Film of Jimi Hendrix Experience at The Marquee playing HEY JOE, his first big hit; Extended Interviews- MORE great stories from his brother Leon and others!; 2 Photo Galleries and also included as a bonus is a 20 page booklet that features some great old photos and concert posters.On September 18, 1970, we heard the news that Jimi Hendrix was dead in England at the young age of 27. We were sad and shocked that drugs took away this rare guitar genius. We started hearing stories that his manager may have had him killed, as Jimi was about to fire him. Stories always abound on a wealthy, young or famous person's death. We didn't know if it was murder, suicide or an accidental drug overdose. After seeing this film, I listened to Eric Burdon tell the story of finding the note Jimi left in his room, after his death. It's words are also on his Grave Monument in Seattle:The story of life is quickerThan the wink of an eyeThe story of love is hello and goodbyeUntil we meet again.To me, this is definitely a farewell note. This dvd is a solid 5 stars and you will feel what it was like to know Jimi Hendrix firsthand through all the great people who have their Jimi stories to share with all of us Jimi Hendrix fans!
summary: PAYING HOMAGE TO THE GREAT JIMI HENDRIX!
